Rarity doesn’t mean anything if no one knows or cares about the cards in question. An upshot of WotC’s ubiquity is that, because everyone had these cards as a kid, a lot of people also have nostalgia for these older sets, and that kind of mass sentimentality makes for a very large market. There might be a lot of (some) WotC sets, but there are also a lot of people who want those cards. So gen 3 cards might be rarer, but that also means far fewer people have this same kind (or at least amount) of organic sentimentality for the cards, because far fewer people collected them when they were first released.

See, the main trick here is whether the new anime is connected to the ashnime or not canonically.
If it is, then you can draw direct comparisons.
If it isn't then we really have to get behind the new characters and premises to make any sort of verdict on it as a show if its own.
The new show also has to VASTLY differ from the ashnime in formula if you want to discuss it as a separate show which meams no tournament faggotry, no catching them all, no contests, no COTD travelling in the forest, no romance subplot arcs, no villain teams, etc.
Basically you'd get something like Digimon or Bakugan.

Also it should NOT be discussed in /padt/ because it's not the Ash show.
The Rikonime should have its own /vp/ general while /padt/ will be used to discuss previous series like OS, DP, XY, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53204636
>>53204668
adding skeletal bits is actually really bad advice and the main reason a lot of fakemon look like fakemon
the only skeletal pokemon we've ever truly had has been Houndstone, and even that's only partially skeleton
most ghost types tend to stick to wispy forms and/or lots of wispy bits, as well as a lot of dark purples/blacks/reds

there's some weird exceptions to the rule like Decidueye and Litwick that hardly look ghostly at all, but in general it's better to stick to:
>darker/more washed-out colors, especially purple/black/yellow for whatever reason (Giratina, Palossand, Shedinja, Cofagrigus- it's weirdly common?)
>either very wispy bodies (Marshadow, Misdreavus, Gastly, Spiritomb) or a very clearly possessed object (Phantump, Chandelure, Banette, Cofagrigus again)
>sunken eyes and/or colored scleras. Also just weird eye shapes in general (Gourgeist, Rotom, Drifblim, Lunala, Dhelmise)

these are all the essential elements to creating a good ghost type, and anything further is either overkill or acceptable as a singular gimmick
newer gens have obviously blurred the rules on this because the longer this franchise goes on the less established conventions it keeps in place in regards to monster design, but Ghosts have been some of the most consistent and consistently good designs in the series and I think this is why

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Torment, combined with Heatran's impressive set of resistances and considerable bulk, turns Heatran into one of the toughest Pokemon to KO in the game. The idea behind this set is that not many Pokemon carry more than one attack powerful enough to break Heatran's Substitutes. With that in mind, Torment allows Heatran to stay safe by using Protect to prevent its opponent from breaking its Substitute with their STAB or super effective attack. That means that every other turn, Heatran can attack with Lava Plume for free without having to worry about being damaged. This set slowly chips away at Heatran's opponent while maintaining Heatran's Substitute at the end of the duel when they faint.

Lava Plume is the move of choice on this set, due to its high PP and 30% burn rate. Many Heatran switch-ins (such as Gyarados, Tyranitar, and Swampert) do not like getting burned. The chance to burn also helps slowly drain the opponent's HP, meaning Heatran does not even have to attack. Instead, it can alternate between Substitute and Protect to rack up residual damage. Taunt is an interesting option over Lava Plume for dealing indirect damage. It prevents Pokemon from healing and forces them to attack Heatran's Substitutes in vain. When combined with Torment, Pokemon such as mono-attacking Blissey and Suicune will struggle every other turn, allowing Heatran to beat certain Pokemon that would otherwise completely counter it; however, Taunt also makes Heatran lose to other Pokemon which Heatran would normally be able to beat. In fact, any Pokemon with more than one attack, or a faster Pokemon with Taunt will be able to beat this set unless they are afflicted with a status condition.
Gen 6 OU

>>53183007
Quite a lot.
Its significantly different to the original BlazedBlack2. Beyond just adding Fairy types, evolutions have been redone, stat trainers have been added, teams for gym leaders and bosses have been redone, certain events have been changed and short cuts like Clay Tunnel are opened up early giving you greater access to monsters in the mid game.
Its certainly not a different hack entirely or anything. But it is an improvement on what was already pretty solid.

>What is Fanfiction/Write Thread? Isn’t it /vpwt/?
Much like Mystery Dungeon General /pmdg/, writefag threads named /vpwt/ are always cursed to die from inactivity, so we’ve had more luck with informal threads. So yes and no, same purpose as /vpwt/ but not cursed. Now, let’s get to the fanfic/writing part

>What are you reading currently?
>What are you writing currently?
>What’s your favorite kind of fic? (Recommendations?)

posts.name: cge0361
posts.com:
>>53154813
>What are you reading currently?
Just proofin' something non-fandom.

>What are you writing currently?
I got half of a chapter on my current WIP, which having been writer's blocked for a few years now will hopefully get over that hump.

>What’s your favorite kind of fic? (Recommendations?)
The kind that challenges its characters to deal with problems, not merely act out "being in the world of the IP" or "let's save the day" kinds of tropes.

>>Which Pokemon do you wish got featured more in stories?
I think that it's good that many species don't get featured much. There are so many kinds of pokemon that it makes sense that some simply don't inhabit places or exhibit behaviors that put it in the kinds of places where interesting fiction happens. The other side of this is that when a rarely featured pokemon appears, it needs to hit a home run and demonstrate what it uniquely has to offer a narrative while also showing that we should be happy not to see it too often. That preserves the mystique and gets the most mileage out of relatively untrodden paths.

>>Author QOTT: What’s one thing about creating a story you wish readers understood better?
That the author has no idea how what's written will be received. Scenes I felt were kinda dull connectors have stolen spotlights and bits I thought were profound have fallen flat. So while compliments on a work as a whole are well appreciated, it's comments on the individual bits that hit or missed that can provide actionable feedback letting the author develop a second-person perspective on how the piece looks to a reader on the other side of the screen.

posts.name: Purple Blaziken
posts.com:
>>53155025
Exactly what you describe in terms of needing to justify the usage of niche species in order to fairly give them a spotlight is what I’m going for in my Mystery Dungeon story. It’s a long story with a big world, so I have a lot in mind to showcase some underloved Pokemon without feeling like they’re being forced into relevance. That’s what I always loved about playing the Mystery Dungeon series and it’s something I’m strongly trying to carry over into my own take on the concept. For example, Diglett or Bidoof or Loudred are not Pokemon I ever would’ve thought could make for entertaining/interesting characters until I saw them in action in Mystery Dungeon. I’d love readers to have that same feeling, that “Aha!” moment that allows them to see a shitmon/obscure pick in a new light.

I also totally love your answer for the QOTT, I feel like that’s something that goes across all entertainment media: painters, musicians, actors, writers; often times it’s the work we expect to hit hard that gets glanced over and the work that we second guess that lands a home run with the audiences. I agree with your note on specific feedback, but think an equally valid way forward (that you could totally do in conjunction) would be to always keep your stories fresh and diverse in terms of emotion, word choice, structure, plot, character, etc; feeling like I’m reading the same chapter twice in a row is my worst feeling as a reader, so it’s my worst fear as an author, I don’t think you should ever let a story stagnate. You can still adjust to your successes and losses and tell a perfectly fluid story without allowing style or standards to stagnate.

Best of luck on clearing your block, you got it!

I've dabbled with something like that, though not for pokemon in particular. As far as I discovered in my brief stint into that sort of thing, it's rather important that you don't think of the story as just a one-to-one extension of exactly what happened in the game. It's difficult to steer away from an outright novelization, but altering in-game and mechanical events to spin your own story/character seems to work out the best. Just off the top of my head, you could write a struggling party member with shit stats or nature as having a completely different made-up problem which then creates a conflict in the story. You'd also probably play the game incrementally with progressing your writing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53168964
I already did. I was the pmd thread critique. I think that your descriptions are weak because you rely too heavily on adverbs and by applying adjectives rather than exploring more interesting ways to convey imagery, as well as falling into telling behavior. But I'll elaborate on that if I must. Let's take something from the second chapter.

>“Buddy, you better watch your mouth,” Zangoose grows super serious, clearly offended and now speaking in a tone that’s making me feel increasingly unsafe.

"Grows super serious" is a telling statement, which is always a weaker alternative to applying context. As is the continuation stating that he's "clearly offended" and "making [Nathan] feel unsafe". This is simply a weak way to demonstrate something that was already given to the reader if only based on what Zangoose had already said. It's pretty clear that he's offended already, and that the Natu is in a precarious position to be pissing people off, but I understand that you wanted to express the change of tone and Nathan's fear. Were I to write out the same thing myself, it'd probably be a bit something like:

>"Buddy, you better watch your mouth," Zangoose snapped. I wince at the tone of his voice, trying to make myself small in my sling, but he continued to shout.

It's maybe not the best, or even what you wanted out of that sentence, but it's not mincing any words. It has a speech tag that assists the sudden shift in tone, a physical reaction from Nathan that denotes his mental state and provides physical imagery, and a way to denote that Zangoose is going to continue speaking.

It's things like that you can improve on with your prose. It should go without saying that having sentences like "Adjacent to this is a gently flowing river of crystal clear freshwater," can be a road bump in the reader's pacing and generally just rambles on implicit details to what you already describe as a vital, life-giving water source.

posts.name: cge0361
posts.com:
>>53169385
Agreed. In addition to the meme baggage of "super serious" (evoking memories of the South Park running gag with Al Gore saying "super cereal" instead as a malaprop) it's also evocative of childish and adolescent speech patterns that use adjectives for superlative emphasis.

The problem with the original line, and what can be improved in Anon's suggestion, is that there is an unexploited opportunity (as Anon mentions) to SHOW Zangoose's emotional transition rather than TELL it after the fact. This needs to be done first, because it colors the spoken part. As originally written—some sort of dialog tag with present tense narration that's jumping out of POV (I presume this is narrator-as-protagonist and doing kind of a stream of consciousness thing to justify present tense) awkwardly for the sake of presuming something—it's closer to a script, which isn't disallowed, but it's easy to get into a habit of just writing the spoken lines and tagging, forgetting that when we shift attention we must refresh the portrayal.

Ex.

(MC says something stupid.)

Zangoose's ears twitched and his eyes narrowed. He squared up his posture and sucked a sharp breath while the fur across his shoulders stood on end. "Buddy," he growled deeply, "you'd better watch your mouth." He leaned in, and I felt so threatened I couldn't help but to sink into my sling, feeling small and needy of protection.

>river thing
This is a fault of overloading one sentence. Long sentences can be cool, but they still need to be about one thing.

"Adjacent to this is a gently flowing river. Its waters are fresh, safe to drink, and crystal clear."

Two sentences cover two separate things—the river as a waterway and the water that flows in said waterway—and allows both to be better served without truly reducing the amount of described detail. Indeed, I've increased it, but it's easier to read because it's following an introduction/description pattern rather than wadding the whole thing up.

>>53155636
Sc 1 - I'm reminded of children's books I read long ago. I would not consider this a good thing.

Sc 2/3 - Were it not for my decision to give the entirety of the first chapter a read-through I would have stopped reading here. Cliche, rote, tired, - take your pick, whatever you like, they are all an accurate summary of these two scenes. Wholly unnecessary and baffling in their inclusion unless the aim is to heap still more young adult fiction onto the already burgeoning pile that exists with little regard for the appetite the audience has for higher lit. Aim for the smaller pile - everyone will be happier for it.

It is not lost on me this is fan fiction, but [good] fan fiction should make you forget that.

Sc 4 - See above.

Sc 5 - My attention unravels.

You show things that aren't necessary, and tell things that are. The overall construction of the work makes it abundantly clear that whoever is penning the prose knows how to write, but only in one specific way, and that way is long past its service-by date.

That's my best attempt at being succinct, because I don't want to spend an hour taking a fine-toothed comb to this. I will instead offer up a suggestion: Read Nisioisin. I feel the author will likely give you plenty of ideas and techniques to chew on that you could integrate into the parts of the work. He's character-focused and dialogue heavy, so he's not a good source for building up skills when it comes to exposition, but there are plenty of authors that do that as is.

Side note: Really, there's no need to run the PMD introduction gauntlet (sc. 2/3). It is exists for and in service of the gameplay, and it has no business being in a piece of prose when what it establishes could be better handled in scenes dedicated to showing what the questions try to illustrate. This is a common pitfall that dozens and dozens of PMD writers fall victim to and it is confusing to me every single time to find yet another body blinking up at me from the hole.

posts.name: cge0361

>>53179891
>I thought most AIs were programmed to explicitly avoid such things.
The general public services are strongly encouraged to censor prompts and output because they can get scapegoated for the prompts of people who might use the tool to break taboos. But it's trivial for someone with beefy GPU to go to a site with tagged art that is relevant to their interests and train on what they want. So, an e6-trained model's going to give e6 kinds of results. (e6 has an AI output counterpart now, btw, but it's very low traffic.)

Caveat emptor, what goes into a model is what comes out. It's like super lossy compression with super error correction on a portfolio to be used for photo collage. I would advise against downloading anything that isn't specifically trained within the art sites that you're comfortable browsing or that comes from dubious sources. I've been sticking to links to one of the least-seedy looking model sites (Civit AI). And once you have one good model, you can play with loras to get a lot of interesting results; they're like game mods and even if it's not for what you intend at low power it can make output a lot less generic.

posts.name: cge0361

>>53180169
There might be some room to play with the raised/trained by pokemon angle insofar as in canon we have people (e.g. psychics, black belts) who train with pokemon and seem to pick up a tiny fraction of the power. Having him raised by the correct species could allow for a human character with interesting poke-characteristics, but only if it's relevant to the core conflict.

Which is missing from this elevator pitch.

There's not much conflict in someone wondering what "kind of pokemon" he is when either he's been among very few kinds (and would know that he's significantly different and be ignorant of the thousand kinds of pokemon that could be alternatives for him to try to identify with) or many kinds (he would presume that he's just another kind that the other pokemon aren't familiar with) and resolving it wouldn't really change him or develop his character. And being not inculcated with complicated philosophical crap like "place in ecosystem/society/etc" to muddy his mind, he would probably figure his place to be wherever he's been, doing what he's been doing.

If the core conflict is wild-man versus society by having him be rediscovered, you've got a lot of fish-out-of-water tropes at hand, most of which having been worked to death already in mass media.

(cont)

posts.name: cge0361
posts.com:
>>53181348
I think a more interesting angle would be to completely avoid humanity and to make this human the plot mechanic: Perhaps amid a desert is a natural spring that has created an oasis. Pokemon living there were divided into two groups that were each internally at peace and cooperative, but avoided each other due to type interactions meaning some of A could beat B but some of B could beat A so if they fought it'd be high casualties for both sides. But now the water is running out and the oasis is shrinking as the plant life withers. The circle is closing in and Battle Royale mode seems unavoidable, soon. The spoiler: B has been raising the lost child of human explorers who perished, and now it's the pokemon of A are the ones trying to figure out what a human is, why it has no familiar powers (or only very slightly picked up from the B pokemon as discussed above), but seems to have other abilities, including that the B pokemon seem to rally around it in ways that pokemon didn't normally behave.

Then the conflict becomes a battle for resources but with a development arc of whether or not Human will continue to function as a pokemon, or if the pressure of a fight for survival will push him into the role of a trainer and develop into a more human personality. That gives the story a question to discuss and answer, allows you to tackle the eternal unresolved nature-nurture topic, shoot your scenes from pokemon perspectives and have an interesting role reversal where the pokemon can talk but the human cannot communicate beyond gestures and familiar vocalizations, and you can avoid lots of the Tarzan Makes Contact tropes that would easily bog things down and make the story pick up some of the feel of a rehash.

>I think it should be that every single story that gets posted here, be it posted by the author or discovered by an anon, should go onto this hypothetical new master list.
That quickly becomes overwhelming and redundant against a link to AO3's search page.

My vision would be two sections.

1. /vpwt/ authors. Handle, link(s) to story galleries, and one sentence to describe the author's work succinctly. That would be easily for new people to scan for things that might be worth a click. It also means a lot of our stories are covered collectively.

2. Non-thread favorites. This would be curated and probably best handled by judging according to how the authors and readers in this thread overall feel about a piece, and would be good for stories that thread authors don't cover. E.g., I don't think anyone here does nuzlocke stories, so if there's a good one, that would be something for section 2.

>lead to elitism
By making everyone in the thread being on the section 1 roster, there's not much room for elitism short of arguing over sorting by alphabetical versus something else. Section 2 would be apolitical unless it's like someone here trying to signal boost a friend who isn't here. I don't think that's much of a problem.

>>53188469
I think it isn't wholly PMD's fault, it's not like it came in and destroyed anything. Rather, pokemon fiction has a few broad categories and mostly this thread was one part lemon and three parts mainline-verse; people in a world with pokemon, be they canon characters or OC's or mary sues.

At about one time, a lot of the mainliners finished stories and either quit to make their own franchises (e.g. Ee4ee) or went on sabbatical from writing in favor of trying other hobbies for a while (e.g. myself), and a new cadre of PMD authors showed up.

If I remember right, it's been a while, we had one guy dropping chapters about weekly on something like a computer programmer with a pokemon in the office (totally not sure if that's right) and three PMD authors pretty much occupying the whole space with PMD. And that's fine except that it means everyone here who was here for Mainline is not getting what they're interested in.

Traffic falls, volunteer thread bumpers become discouraged when all the posts are bumps between PMD drops that no longer get any discussion because so many people have drifted away.

And then there's the Discord which simply doesn't make sense since writing isn't a real time communications game, and the ease to read /vpwt/ isn't matched by Discord, where either the chatter causes any insightful discussion to scroll away swiftly, or it's not convenient to find new posts (especially if it's split across channels), making it a poor substitute for the thread.

/vpwt/ is great for writing because you can write, when you need a break check the thread, then go write again. A writer doesn't need the distraction of Discord making bloop noises and putting red dots with numbers in them on your screen. At least, I know that I sure don't.

The last time normal OP was used was in December according to archive. Here it is.

>post fanfics you like
>share your own fics, ask for advice, post story updates
>discuss writerly struggles with fellow writefriends

Previous Thread: >>52760169

Check out the catalog for a directory of fics from fellow writefags: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1PtN4D_9CSw8JJ9uO6v0oQqdtKEkS8aFAvfxqI96XfSE
Gallery of art drawn for stories in the thread: https://imgur.com/a/sjdck

>Can I post NSFW fics?
There are no rules against NSFW text links.

>How should I post my fics?
If it's short enough to fit into a couple of posts, posting to the thread is fine. If you want to share longer works, or if you want more permanent storage, you can link to a host: fanfiction.net, AO3, Pastebin, or Google Docs.

>I'm not a writer but I want to contribute
Feel free to give stories posted a read and critique as you see fit. Keep it relevent to the story.
>Can I request something?
You're encouraged to post prompts, i.e. short snippets or greentext sequences describing your ideas. You can also expand on prompts posted by others. If writing an entire story from start to finish feels too daunting, this is a way to get started.

>I have this idea about [event/technology/...]
Feel free to post your thoughts about how specific parts of the Pokémon world function as well. Worldbuilding is always welcome.

>Can I add a fic I wrote to the catalog?
Check the catalog for the submission link. Fill out the form with all the necessary information and it will be submitted for review automatically.

We're also looking to collect ideas for fanfics as a resource for stumped writers. Feel free to throw an idea out there; someone may choose to use it themselves!
Ideabin: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1X072SSWulcC6RJRrPA6v9XtyohRybvMBl6Fh49wHsRw

Starting with a conjunction is fine when it's quoted (because people to speak like that; often indicating that something related came to the speaker's mind as the prior sentence ended) and when it's elaborating on the topic (on-topic enough for the same paragraph) but isn't elaborating on the previous sentence itself but rather the paragraph topic so it wouldn't be appropriate to stitch them together with a semicolon but just spouting the second sentence without a conjunction makes the sentences seem unrelated.

The danger is when it becomes a habit and turns a writer's work into run on sentences "fixed" by periods before the running-on conjunction. It's almost as bad as meaningless "like" infestation in spoken English.

>>53190015
The question then becomes what prose to choose.

I must confess, I hardly read any "traditional" prose these days due to the deluge of books out on the market. It's not easy to discern what would be to one's taste *and* of decent quality. For a medium like fanfiction, there's no cost in testing the waters of a work and skipping around real quick to discern if it is something worth your time or not.

With dead paper tree format, digital works only offer so many pages as a demo, often the best sliver of it while leaving out the rest that may as well be dumpster trash. As for going to the actual bookstore, the only indication you have of any interest is the back cover and trying to peruse books real quick one at the time. This wouldn't be a problem, save for the fact that I don't go out often these days due to various IRL issues, meaning the opportunity to scan a book's contents in depth is limited. Even if I were to get the opportunity, it takes time to discern for more traditional fare to be dissected in depth before knowing if it's worth my time or not. One way I have gotten passed this is by photographing the book's front cover and checking out a... Find in the great sea as it were, which helps alleviates this somewhat. But it isn't as convenient as just plucking a hyperlink and perusing at will.

Still, online platforms where semi traditional prose such as Royal Roads has a nice selection, provided the author doesn't pull a shit move by skubbing the work and taking it to Amazon only. Calibre/fanficfare has been helpful in this regard in preserving the works when I find them, but it's annoying when it happens.

Not to mention, quite of the few writers I have read from often have recommendations to other works that might be of interest to me. Still, there's such a volume online that it's hard to know where to start sometimes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53194635

>>53189253
>One of my biggest pet peeves is how many writer treat pokemon as nothing more then props instead of their own character. The protag interaction with his pokemon would create interesting interaction and dilemma.

That may be a symptom of one just playing the games only, or perhaps just as how the anime sometimes treat their Pokemon characters. Unlike Digimon, Pokemon are, or at least were as far as my knowledge of the anime up to the Hoenn region is concerned, treated as less of a focused narrative importance. That isn't to say they don't always do so, such as with legendaries, Ash's starter and other mons, and the like, but it probably reflects on how a writer illustrates their own mons going forward.

Aside from that, there's also the matter of how a writer interprets their mons based on their own head canon, the anime, games, and so on. Some writers just don't give a damn, often caring more for the human characters as a focus and the mons being more or less vehicles to get from Point A to Point B. For those that don't, their mons tend to trend towards a more humanistic interpretation, if not outright humans in fursuits. Not that isn't a bad thing necessarily, but it's a fine balance that some just don't want to tightrope on.

That, and the more focus you give to the mons as actual characters, the more characters you have to juggle in your head to keep track of. Focusing strictly on the trainer means you have less moving pieces to worry about. Even if you were to stick with just six mons in total, that's *still* six characters and the dynamics you have between them and the trainer you have to keep track of at all times. It can get messy *real* quick if you don't keep a careful track of it all and devolve into an incoherent, unholy mess of threads that never get resolved and other stuff. God help you if you decide to try and add more and more characters to the fire as the trainer in question catches more.

With that out of the way, I have a question for the writers of this thread in concerns with visualization and conceptualization of any given scene.

How do you visualize and construct a scene? Where do you start? What prompts it? What material do you use as fuel for such? What sources of inspiration do you draw upon? How do you get past the brain fog that may arise when attempting to write something?

When starting a given chapter, what is your focus when starting the scene to springboard off of? What is the transition from one end of a chapter to the beginning of another?

---
And the finally, how do you troubleshoot your own work?

Even when I have it pointed out by others, I still find difficulties in troubleshooting my first draft on a reading due to the personal preference in my reading style and reading speed. Just recently, I have been told that my work often has passages that are overly long and rarely varied in their cadence, meandering longer than they should have instead of being quick and decisive. My question then becomes how do I spot and focus on those errors in the first place? Better yet, how do I at least mitigate it in the first draft? I know it is bad practice to attempt to correct and repair while in the middle of your first draft, but I am of the belief it would be better to nip such bad habits and errors in the bud early, rather than make more work for myself. come the second and third draft revisions.

Woith that in mind, what set of practices would be optimal to mitigate any corrections that need to be made come the 2nd and 3rd draft?

>>53194670
>How do you visualize and construct a scene?
I have a director’s brain so I see the whole stage, I start by visualizing the start and end of the scene, then I find the most natural and satisfying way to bridge the two. Always know where you’re going and how you’re getting there.
>Where do you start?
At the beginning. Readers don’t get hooked in the 3rd quarter of a chapter, you should always start at the part that matters. If you don’t have a good beginning, no one will be reading come the ending.
>What prompts it?
I can write at any time, I’ve never really suffered from any major block.
>What material do you use as fuel for such?
Not entirely sure what you mean by this when compared to the next question, but if by material you mean other prose then none, you’re doing yourself and your readers a disservice if you’re “fueling” yourself with other people’s work, that’s no way to find your own voice.
>What sources of inspiration do you draw upon?
Music, nothing puts a clearer head for a scene, character, or story in my mind than music; I always listen while writing, I get the most vivid visuals in my mind. Certain songs, albums, or artists will in turn end up being delegated to certain characters, stories, plots, etc.
>How do you get past the brain fog that may arise when attempting to write something?
When you’re doing choral vocal warmups, you have to visualize the highest and lowest notes you intend to hit or else your unrelaxed vocal chords will have no hope of hitting them. Writing works very much the same way, if you jump from fucking around online to writing you’re gonna have a slow start, you need to begin all writing with a clear mind and a clear purpose, never write out of necessity or obligation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53194670
>>53194919
>When starting a given chapter, what is your focus when starting the scene to springboard off of?
Your chapter should have an overall purpose and an overall conflict, and both of those things should at the very least be alluded to in the first scene of the chapter, but more often than not you should want your audience to be able to identify those things from that first scene. Chapters aren’t just linebreaks in walls of text, they’re all microcosmic stories building to the larger narrative, they should have the same orientation with which you aim to get your overall story across.
>What is the transition from one end of a chapter to the beginning of another?
Read the above response, you sound like a meanderer, writing with no purpose or vision for chapters.
>And the finally, how do you troubleshoot your own work?
You can’t without other people. Tell your proofreaders or critics or whoever is giving you feedback to cite specific passages from the text that suit their criticism, have them explain why they feel it didn’t work, and what they would have rather read there. Feedback like that is the only true way to improve, you can’t troubleshoot your own work. A faulty engineer isn’t going to realize the fatal flaw in their vehicle while constructing it.

posts.name: Mimiga
posts.com:
>>53194670
Though it may come with its own set of issues and pitfalls, my creative process greatly relies on music for its juice. Mostly actual first-party music, but anything that paint the picture will do and it doesn't pay to be picky if it conjures up a scene regardless. Often times this means that the general tone, cadence, and even structure of a scene, chapter, or story may be dictated by the sound design and lyrical gravity of the song I felt would inspired the most. There are songs which provide narrative texture and inform me of directions I would like a story to go, and songs which I take the structure of and translate more or less literally into the choreography of a scene as if it were already scoring it. Many aspects of my stories have been enriched where they wouldn't have been because of an idea/feeling that a song gave. This also helps in that you can dip back into a certain artist or album whenever you lack drive and want to put yourself back into the headspace of the story.

The second question is more nebulous. Scenes should start by establishing everything they need to allow the reader to put themselves where they need to be. Though there are many approaches and it's not necessarily a science for me, I try to establish the narrator's PoV first (I usually only write in Third Person Limited). If not that, then usually a piece of scenery or imagery that I want to focus on first to set the scene. It's just a matter of cinematography. Where is the camera pointing first when it all switches over? Are there characters speaking, and is what they're saying more important than the immediate surroundings? Chapters end when they end, and they begin the next time there is important information for the reader to know.

Troubleshooting is easier because I have spent years and years comparing my work to my peers, have had them comparing to mine, reading different works and being read by more well-read individuals. It's largely experience.

I want to write something but it would be my first time ever writing fan fiction, should I read some literature first to get some ideas?
I know I could just write whatever I want right now and get better over time but I want to do things the right way.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53197421
First do some reading about writing basics: story structures, show don't tell, themes, scene setting, characterization, etc. Just some articles that will help give you an understanding of what you want to absorb from the books you read. Then find some literature that seems interesting to you and have at it. Try to spend some time thinking critically about how they approached those writing concepts and how you might use those ideas.

Spending the effort to learn about how to write well will put you in a much better starting position, but more importantly it will help you gain more from your first attempts where fanfic writers are often just flailing wildly and learning very little from the effort.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53197421
Study the basics of how to write a story, but don't get lost in theory. It's better to try writing and fail than spend days trying to come up with the perfect "theory" and not even pick up a pencil.

There is no "right way", but you're better off just jumping into the deep end than spending the time trying to "prepare" yourself. Just write, the rest will come naturally.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53197421
Write something short. If you do a novel-length story and it sucks, you’ll feel like you wasted time. Start small, do a short story, get feedback, and when you do your next one be sure to use the good feedback you get. Do this ten times and you’ll be way better than you are now.

>It's small therefore it's bad

Route 33 is a great example of Johto synergy.

>Connects to Union Cave and Slowpoke Well, which both open up for further exploration after getting Surf and Strength
>Easily accessible by flying to Azalea (a location which you will want to revisit frequently to get Apricorn Balls from Kurt)
>Contains Hiker Anthony, so you can get his number to get info on Dunsparce swarms. He also has a decent team to rebattle
>There's even a Berry bush so you get a little treat if you revisit each day

As others have pointed out, if this route was in SWSH you would breeze through it in seconds and have no reason to come back

I don't think Gamefreak quite realized how powerful a x1.5 boost is, given how in early gens you had a lot of pokemon that were just expected to make do with random Normal moves off of a high attack stat rather than having an actual useable STAB.
STAB is certainly good to have, since otherwise it just devolves into only wanting optimal coverage, but if STAB were only 1.2 or 1.3 it might make things revolve around it less, and reduce some of the gap between mons with good or bad STAB.

>Some shit like Sobble or Scorbunny tries way too hard to be cute, but the best ones are always mon like Spheal or Mareep who can pull off the cuteness while maintaining good proportions and functioning without snapping their necks at the slightest movement

I can't help but feel something is artificial about them. The illusion of them being natural to their habitat just doesn't jive with me, especially when you look at their latter form. It's probably just me, but when comparing scorbunny to something like mudkip, I can't help but feel something is off when compared to the former. They both have the same beady black eyes to them, a roughly analogous head to body proportion, with the only difference between them being typing, color, and the number of legs that they stand on.

Hell, even their limbs are blobby as well. But no matter how long I look at scorbunny and the likes of sobble, it feels like something is off no matter what.

It's annoying, not being able to pin down the precise factors that just rub me off the wrong way about the newer starters. Even knowing that they were purpose made to be mascots, something still feels off about them even when compared to other purpose built mascots from the past.

Is it the proportions? The shape? The concept? I can only guess.

Oh well, have a cute chikorita.

It's just a vestigial trait that hasn't aged well.

>>53206848
Noland has Pinsir because they needed more Bug-types at the launch of the game and as the Frontier Brain of the Battle Factory, you can give him whatever. The only other Bug-type pair when the game launched was Bugsy & Beedrill. It's the same reason Thorton was in at launch and was paired with Bronzong. It seems to match him better than Pinsir does Noland, but it was chosen because the only other Steel-type pair was Wikstrom & Aegislash.

During Anniversary 2021, there were three Master Fair characters, these are the characters they want you to drop gems on. Lillie & Lunala (it's not Nebby, she says she received it as a Cosmog from the Gen VII MC), N & Reshiram (he already had Zekrom, and he just vaguely alludes that he met and befriended Reshiram after traveling with Zekrom following the ending of BW), and Steven & Rayquaza. The last one is pure fanservice since Zinnia already pairs up with Rayquaza in the game, but his is shiny and can Mega Evolve (unfortunately it's pretty shit due to awful stats). They tie it into his fascination with rocks extending to meteors. Then when they did the Hoenn chapter of the Villain arc, they released Sygna Suit Steven & Deoxys which actually flowed really well with what they had already written. They try to redo the Delta Emerald plot of going to stop a meteor that's going to hit the island and is causing Kyogre and Groudon to go nuts, and only Steven's Rayquaza can Mega Evolve to do it. However, a meteor piece broke off and Deoxys came from it, and it kept going after them and impeding their progress because Deoxys and Rayquaza are rivals in media. Eventually he manages to subdue and catch it while Zinnia manages to finally get her Rayquaza to Mega Evolve and take out the meteor.

They're finally upgrading Leon so his Charizard can Gigantamax, so it's likely we'll see similar upgrades for Maxie and Archie in the future. Lusamine has Pheromosa because she resembles it. Sygna Suit characters are their "serious" outfits.

On top of that, the new catch would be another pet, and depending on how exotic it is, it would be REALLY hard catering to its needs. If I was a pokemon trainer in this scenario, I'd probably catch-and-release just to fill out dex entries but have at most 2-3 pokemon I can take care of, like a Butterfree or something.

It’s the fangame equivalent of a totaled car, the effort required to fix what you already have is greater than the value of the finished product would end up being.

>>53201884
decided to backtrack and post story from then anyways
-
It'd been about a week since Hannah's solitary triumph at Elesa's gym. By now, the group were ready to move on from Nimbasa, and leave it and Tex behind.

They crossed the Dritfveil bridge, exchanging pleasantries and trying to make their circumstances slightly less awkward, eventually arriving where they'd initially intended to end up...
...Driftveil.

The city was... a little less spectacular than Pillow had imagined. Mostly a collection of warehouses and large one-story homes. The most notable building to its name was the church on a hill in the north, and maybe the mines even further north than that.

Regardless of its plain qualities, Pillow was... relieved. Relieved to be here. She'd accomplished something, and this city was quaint- much unlike the hustle and bustle of the last few they'd visited. The change was quite refreshing, and such a sentiment was soon echoed by Sylvia.

The group promptly split, just for a moment. Tea and Hairdo wanted to find where the gym was, while Sylvia and Pillow decided to go and hang out near the Cold Storage in the north. Hannah tagged along for the company, though she didn't talk much.

When the girls got there, however, they were given plenty to talk about.
That Beheeyem pair and their Braviary boss could be spotted once again, up on a podium and seemingly trying to rile up the Pokemon living there- spouting untruths about how Pokemon had been treated as second-class citizens, and citing the contempt the workers of the Storage had for the wilds living there. The tactic seemed to be working, as the small crowd of mon that'd gathered around the mysterious trio seemed rather loud and excited.

So excited, in fact, that a Herdier in the crowd quickly took notice of the newcomers I've been documenting and rushed to hold up Hannah specifically as an example.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53204714
"Look, look!" the Herdier exclaimed, holding up a claw to the Bolt badge shining on Hannah's shoulder. "You're right, Mr Ghetsis sir! This Boldore even has a badge bolted right into her shoulder!"
An ineffectual paw at the accessory yielded little movement, prompting the dog to continue with a slightly more disgusted expression. "I bet her trainer forced her to fight until she was exhausted, and made the badge this way so that he could show off!"

This stranger was, of course, smacked away by Hannah soon after. The only reason she hadn't done so sooner was purely due to how tired she was after Nimbasa. In that respect, the Herdier had a point. Hannah could really use some time to rest after that.

The Braviary called back, though, a grin forming on his beak as the entire crowd turned to the new trio. He quickly affirmed the Herdier's train of thought, giving a sharp nod toward the Herdier and continuing to make an example of Hannah. "Truly despicable behavior. But it's to be expected from humankind, now isn't it?"

Pillow and Sylvia just watched on in exasperation as the crowd began to slowly cut them off from her. It didn't seem an intentional effort- it was too scattershot for that- but it did make things much harder for the two mon who actually KNEW Hannah, and wanted to prevent her identity from being twisted into one of victimhood. Eventually, the crowding got so bad that Sylvia attempted to Slash her way through, only to be instantly bombarded by a crowd of already-riled-up attendees.
Pillow quickly came to her aid, as did Hannah, though the crowd proved hard to beat back. Hannah especially nearly drowned in the swarm, only making her way out of it by creating an entire cage of rocks around her with her Rock Slide attack.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53204769
Eventually, however, the trio beat back the majority of the now-rioters. Only a few were left standing- one of which was a small Deerling, unsure of the situation and more than willing to kowtow to Hannah and profusely apologize. She introduced herself as Pansy- a well-liked member of the Cold Storage wilds who'd migrated there from Route 6- before immediately taking responsibility and offering to help the group with any expenses they might accrue as result of the mob.
Thankfully, those totalled to a three-digit number, but the Deerling found herself wanting to stick with the group regardless. So she took them on a tour of the city once the payment was well and done, too. Just for good measure.

From there, the girls reunited with the boys and told of all that'd happened. Their goal returned to beating the gym, though where to go from there... not many of them were sure.

>>53204589
>Are there other really strange ways you can access certain items in Pokémon games?
If you want a Black Belt or Silver Powder in RSE, you need to rematch a specific Black Belt and Bug Maniac respectively multiple times. But they don't give you the held item for winning, you have to use Thief or Covet to steal it from the specific pokemon holding the item.

And this is just for some held items that offer a 10% type-specific boost in that generation. It's not like it's Leftovers, Choice Band, or something else strong that would potentially warrant jumping through the hoops. I think it's actually a cool idea that encourages rematches, but the payoff just doesn't quite match up.

Silver powder in HGSS can only be obtained via wild Butterfree or Masquerain, which each have a 5% chance to hold it when encountered. Wild Masquerain can only be found in the Safari Zone, not battled, so Thief can't be used. Wild Butterfree can be found by headbutting trees in Ilex Forest and Route 47 (this requires waterfall), in the grass of Route 2 and Viridian Forest (which are post-game), and during the 20-minute bug-catching contest hosted every other day (this is the only way to encounter it in SoulSilver; the other methods are only in Heartgold).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53207061
While the introduction of Fairy types was quite cool (in sense there hasn’t been any new types introduced since 2000 in GS), Mega Pokemon were a genuinely great idea. While I am annoyed that some Pokémon got them that didn’t need them (Salamence and Metagross being prime offenders), it breathed new life into Pokémon that needed the support (Pinsir, Manectric, Kangaskhan, etc.) and gave some older ones new tools to play around with (Heracross, Beedrill, Aerodactyl, Swampert). I’m hopeful GameFreak returns to them one day because there is still a lot of potential for them (E.g. Flygon). Additionally, the online features (PSS) and other introductions (Super Training, Amie, Soaring and DexNav in ORAS) were all brilliant and it is sad to see that the franchise as a whole with these QoL regress a decade.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53185858
The devs decided to determine Spinda's pattern by splitting the 32-bit personality value into 4 8-bit chunks that represent each spot's y and x positions:
>first 4 bits: left face spot y coordinate
>next 4 bits: left face spot x coordinate
>next 4 bits: right face spot y coordinate
>next 4 bits: right face spot x coordinate
>next 4 bits: left ear spot y coordinate
>next 4 bits: left ear spot x coordinate
>next 4 bits: right ear spot y coordinate
>last 4 bits: right ear spot x coordinate

Those last 8 bits are also used to calculate gender, which is done by checking if that chunk is greater or equal to a specific value. On a mon with a 1:1 ratio like Spinda, this works out so that the first 4 bits of the gender chunk in male mons are always* greater or equal to 8 - since this is also the y-coordinate of the right ear spot (keep in mind that vidya coordinates almost always treat positive y as down), male Spinda always* have lower spots than females.

*Incidentally, the gender ratio actually is skewed in favor of males, but only because the programmers used a greater than equal comparison instead of a greater one - the real ratio is 129/127. As such, there's a 1/129 chance that a male Spinda can have the same right ear spot height as a female.

'Face' spots are moved down from their initial position, and 'right' spots are moved to the right. posts.name: Anonymous

>>53192302
I am glad you and others are enjoying the tread. I am surprised and happy that it is still going.

Here is Spinda pattern 0x88888888 in Pokémon Alpha Sapphire. It turned out to be not too much more harder to make than the gen 5 Spinda I posted earlier in this thread. Starting in gen 6 the Encryption Constant starts generally taking on some of the roles of the Personality Value so I just had to put 88888888 in the Encryption Constant instead of the Personality value to make it work. When transferring Pokémon from gen 5 to gen 6 the Encryption Constant is set to the Personality Value. This pattern looks pretty nice in 3D. This should mean that most patterns should translate reasonably well into 3D but I guess that someone would need to see the pattern they wanted for themselves in the game to be sure.

Neither of my posts are incorrect. The only way to go from Blackthorn to Route 44 is through the Ice Path, there is no other direct path that doesn't result in the player warping somewhere else. There's no need for them to be connected ingame.
And Johto does in fact require gates to split up the areas, as you can see in that image. Warping to another area resets the sprites that are loaded into memory, and GSC can only have a relatively small amount of different sprites loaded at once, and even fewer if they have a walk cycle.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
How is this even a question? Gen II has CLONING. Nothing is limited. Want an Espeon and Umbreon but don't want to breed an additional Eevee and raise it all the way up? Raise the regular to max friendship normally, clone it, and level both up at different times.

Want all three starters? Avoid saving until the end of the process and figure out what starter you want your rival to have for the game you stay with (ie. you want your rival to have Totodile so the final starter you choose is Cyndaquil). Choose your first starter, get to the point where can catch another Pokémon, deposit your starter in the PC, switch boxes, turn off the power around DON'T TURN OFF THE P-, and load up a new game. Choose a different starter, catch another Pokémon, the first starter should still be in the PC, deposit the second starter, repeat the glitch, choose your final starter in final new game, you can save now. The other two starters are in your PC, but not in your Pokédex. You have to breed their eggs to get their first stages registered, but evolution will register the other forms. And you'll get bonus experience since they'll have the IDs and OTs of the previous files.

Stones limited in GS? Have Pokémon hold them and then clone them. Worried about coming across a shiny that flees/explodes or sick of dealing with Raikou, Entei, and Suicune? Clone the Master Ball just in case.

In gen 1 they could be paralysed by body slam and thunder wave, but not by damage-dealing electric moves. This is because gen 1 was coded so moves that can inflict status as a secondary effect never do so against a target of the same type as the move. For most part that makes sense: flamethrower won't burn a fire type, poison sting won't poison a poison type, etc. But it does have the odd side-effect of making normal types unable to be paralyzed by body slam.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53201653
In Gen I and II, the defeated Pokémon's base stats are given as EVs. That's why people call it stat experience for those games, because you're no longer gaining 1-3 points per battle where a stat caps at 255 (252 Gen VI+).

If you defeat a Pidgey, you get
>HP: 40
>Attack: 45
>Defense: 40
>Speed: 56
>Special: 35
And stat experience caps at 65535 per stat. The way the math works, it's the same as having 63 additional points by level 100 like EVs, the math is just more unwieldy. The other difference is that there's no collective 510 cap (or equivalent 131,070), you can raise every stat by its maximum 63 points.

Where things get a bit more complex is IVs (or DVs which is how people differentiate them from IVs). IVs are 0-31 and serve as that many extra points at level 100. DVs are 0-15, and that value multiplied by 2 is the extra points, so it's actually +2, +4, +6... ...+30 max. DVs are generated for Attack, Defense, Special, and Speed (this is the order by the way), and the HP DV is the first bit of each. So if your DVs for those four stats are all 8 (1000) or higher, your HP is a guaranteed 15 (1111).
0000 = 0, 1000 = 8
0001 = 1, 1001 = 9
0010 = 2, 1010 = 10
0011 = 3, 1011 = 11
0100 = 4, 1100 = 12
0101 = 5, 1101 = 13
0110 = 6, 1110 = 14
0111 = 7, 1111 = 15
Now the problem is that the RNG in the game isn't perfect and doesn't generate every combination (65,536) of DVs. It does for Pokémon of certain encounter types and area encounter frequencies, but perfect DVs aren't possible for a number of Pokémon because of the areas they're found in. Mind you with breeding in Gen II, this should mostly be fixable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53201867
You're right that it takes a level up for it to calculate new stat experience, but you can also do it by depositing the Pokémon, switching boxes, and switching back. The game doesn't keep the stats of Pokémon in other boxes memorized like it does for your current box and party, only their levels, DVs, and stat experience, so it just recalculates your stats when you switch a box to your current box. It does this to save space, and doing so will apply accrued stat experience.

>>53201875
https://www.smogon.com/forums/threads/15-15-15-15-dvs-are-impossible-in-most-cases.3573219/
This thread goes into more detail.

To put the stat experience thing into more perspective, let's say you're playing an emulator and you've hacked Pidgey and Rattata's base stats to 255 in every stat so you can just grind Route 1. It would take you 257 battles to max all your stats.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53202096
Well in Gen I, all Trainer Pokémon have 0 stat experience themselves, while their DVs are are the same across the board.
Also I was wrong, it's the last bit that's taken to calculate the HP DV, not the first, so if every DV is an odd number (ends in a 1), the HP DV will be perfect. In Gen I, all Trainer DVs are 1001/1000/1000/1000 (9/8/8/8 for Atk/Def/Spd/Spe), making HP 1000 (8). All Trainer movesets use the Pokémon's most recently learned 4 moves, which is why Pokémon that evolve from stones are pretty gimped when used by NPCs and is why your rival's Exeggutor only has 3 moves.

In Gen II, DVs are determined by Trainer class (specifically Trainer sprite, so both rival sprites count as different classes, each Gym Leader, each Elite Four, etc.), and it's like that from that game onward. Red is 15/13/13/14 (1110 = 14 HP). I assume Stadium has more thought put into it, because apparently the Battle Tower in Crystal gives every Trainer custom DVs and stat experience.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: IIRC in gen 4 the way the Cute Charm ability's secondary effect (increase the chance to encounter pokemon of the opposite gender to 66,6 % if the pokemon with the ability was in your 1st slot) worked was that if the ability activated the game would not randomize the wild pokemon's stats as normal, and instead randomly determine the pokemon's nature and then assign it IVs based on a template (one for each nature) generated based on your hidden trainer ID generated when you start a new game. Because shinies were also determined by IVs it was possible have a hidden ID that causes pokemon of one nature spawned through Cute Charm to always be shiny, massively increasing the odds of finding a shiny (66,6 % chance the ability triggers when you encounter a wild pokemons and 4 % chance it has the right nature, which is still far better than the 0,025 % chance you normally have of finding a shiny). Of course, the odds of getting the right hidden ID by chance is atronomically low, but people did figure how to manipulate the RNG to ensure you get it.

Since there's been a few posts about Unown ITT, here's another one. All the Gen 3 Unown cards have Hidden Power attacks which borrow their effects from other Pokémon whose attacks' first letter matches the letter of the Unown.

This happened after NOA/TPCi took over translation of the card game from WOTC, and is effectively an easter egg that most Japanese players/collectors probably never noticed, if any ever did.

>>53202359
I was starting to think that maybe they meant something like that, like every name is in an array.

If we're talking obscure facts, I pull this one out like maybe once a year. I went through all the Trainer names in Japanese GS. People usually know this, but there are Trainers whose names are references to people, like Trainers who are named Ikue from game to game using Pikachu. This started in Gen II, and it extends to practically every character in the game in Japanese, rarely is a name just a name. From characters like Schoolboy Manabu (学ぶ is the verb to learn) and Bird Keeper Tsubasa (翼 means wing) to Poké Fan Megumi named after Megumi Hayashibara and practically every staff member on the credits being referenced as a character somewhere in the game. There are even some really obscure ones, like Atsuko (after Atsuko Nishida) only appearing as a wrong name when you get misdialed by Picnicker Liz, same with Tsunekazu (Tsunekazu Ishihara) with someone from the lighthouse. It's impossible to tell practically any of references outside of the Japanese games. But what's even crazier is that 4Kids actually used Nintendo's localized English names if the corresponding Japanese name appeared in the Johto anime. In The Legend of Thunder, there's Jimmy (Kenta) and Vincent (Jun'ichi), whose names 4Kids decided on because of the NPCs Youngster Kenta (Jimmy) and Guitarist Jun'ichi (Vincent), who also happened to be Gen II's Masuda reference (Guitarist Masuda in Crystal's Battle Tower isn't in the Japanese game because of how the Battle Tower was altered). You can find more examples in random filler episodes of the Johto anime.

In the Gen III games, even though a number of names were reused, they were given different translated names. And because Gen I NPCs were getting names in FRLG, a lot of those Hoenn names carry over to them. Eventually the localization ended up having to integrate the older Gen II names to maintain consistency.

Nintendo have no sway, you little shithead, due to how the thing got birthed. They were hands-off as they didn't want to waste time training Game Freak to make a game, beyond seconding Miyamoto to them, to advise as soft producer. RG launched, took off and Nintendo pushed for the next game in 1997. And waited. And waited. Then Nintendo sent in Iwata to unfuck the process and had to wait a further year and a half. Nintendo learned early to not push Game Freak, because they made potted gold anyway, harebrained and scattered as their dev cycles were. >>53200522
>All of the megas have sprites but none of the gigantamax mons have sprites, I guess they're only considering megas as a returning gimmick from this point onward.
Those images come from Home usage ranking, that should explain it.
Mega is a permanent in-battle form: if you include a Charizard with the Mega stone in your team, it will be Mega Charizard. For the duration of the battle
If you include a Charizard with GMAX factor in your team, it will not be GMAX Charizard the whole time. It will only be transformed for 3 turns or never at all, you can have it fight the whole battle as regular Charizard.

In simple terms, using a pokémon with Mega Stone = using a Mega pokémon. But using a Pokémon with GMAX factor =/= using a GMAX Pokémon. So GMAX is not included in "usage statistics".
